results.title: Short poppies 2
results.brief_description: Short poppies is a competitive film and video festival open to university and college students from around the world. This collection of ten productions has been selected from the second festival which opened at Kinselas night club in Sydney on July 7th 1994. The films were judged by a panel of filmmakers, critics and students and award winning work then toured around Australia to all capital cities. The short films included originate from Canada, Australia, United Kingdom and Germany, the titles of which are: “Rokadeus”, “The stranger”, “Bear in mind, “Memory snares”, “Bete noire”, “Talk show”, “Pet”, “Schlaraffenland”, “Miss Dudevant’s hand”, and “Beatrix and Marvin”.

results.title: Short history = Scurta istorie
results.creator_credit: Ion Popescu Gopo and Studioul Cinematografic Bucuresti
results.brief_description: Using animation techniques presents a complete history of mankind from the birth of the Earth, showing man as a descendant of an ape. Taking with him everywhere a symbolic flower he explores the planet, optimistically considering life under water, and eventually, life on other planets of the cosmos.

results.title: Shopping in Japan: an invitation to quality
results.brief_description: Retail traders in Japan offer a very wide range of quality consumer goods to the people of Japan and vistors to the country. These include goods made in both the traditional manner by craftsmen in home industries and in small vilalge factories, and those made in the new efficient industrial complexes.

results.title: Shoot the nets
results.creator_credit: Herman Van Der Horst and Cinetone Studios
results.brief_description: Herring fishing in the North Sea, following a group of Dutch boats on a typical cruise. A documentary record of a Dutch trawler on its annual voyage to the Dogger Bank, fishing ground for herring. Shows the ceremonies and celebrations that usher in the herring fishing season, decking of boats with flags and departure of the fleet to the international fishing grounds. The nets are put out, the crew wake in the middle of the night for the laborious business of hauling in the catch, a storm comes up and the fleet turns home. The film stresses the cooperation at sea among fishermen of different nations who rely on the Dogger Bank for their livelihood.

results.title: Ship-Busters
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Royal Air Force. Film Production Unit
results.brief_description: A tribute to the British Dominion Allied Squadrons of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command who took part in the campaign against German-controlled shipping along the coast of Europe during the years 1939-45. The R.A.F. in Norway during WWII.

results.title: Shine, Sir!
results.creator_credit: Kiwi Polish Company and The London Press Exchange
results.brief_description: An early advertising film, using animation, which promotes Australian made Kiwi boot and shoe polish and a fair capitalist system that allows for the initiative of youngsters. The ‘Imperial Hotel’ is left short staffed during World War I. Two young boys apply for the position of boot boys, but lament that they can’t clean boots. An Australian soldier, overhearing their conversation, offers each of them a tin of Kiwi boot polish which has impressive results and secures employment for them at the hotel.

results.title: Sheridan's world of society: 18th century London (TEFC)
results.brief_description: In 1777 Sheridan was the leading dramatist at age 26, and his “School for Scandal” was playing to packed houses. Filmed from original art work from the period, with voiceover, this film surveys life in London at the time. Peoples of different levels of society are seen - in parks, in business, in coffee houses, in shops, in fashion and in the arts. At the end there is a quick biography of Sheridan from this time until his death 30 years later.

results.title: Shelter (USA)
results.brief_description: This film traces man’s growing ability to change the form of materials, and shows how the development of transportation has increased the variety and the supply of raw materials available to man, for building himself shelter from the elements. Examples range from African grass huts and Eskimo igloos to skyscrapers and individual homes in and industrialized country.
